title: Goldbach analog for cyclics
stmt: Every even n ∈ N greater than 2 is a sum of two cyclics.

title: twin cyclics analog
stmt: There are infinitely many cyclics c ∈ C such that c + 2 is also cyclic.

title: cyclic triplets
stmt: There are infinitely many composite cyclics c ∈ C such that c, c + 2, c + 4 are all composite cyclic.

title: cyclic quintuplets
stmt: There are infinitely many cyclics c ∈ C such that c, c + 2, c + 4, c + 6, c + 8 are all cyclic.

title: Legendre analog for cyclics
stmt: For every n ∈ N, there exists a cyclic c ∈ C such that n2 < c < (n + 1)2.

title: Desboves analog for cyclics
stmt: For every n ∈ N, there exist two cyclics c, c′ ∈ C such that n2 < c < c′ < (n + 1)2.

title: Deligne’s conjecture: primes in intervals between successive squares
stmt: As n → ∞, the number NP(n) of primes in the interval (n2, (n + 1)2) satisfies NP(n) ∼ n/ log n.

title: cyclics in intervals between successive squares
stmt: As n → ∞, the number Nc(n) := #{c ∈ C | c ∈ (n2, (n + 1)2)} of cyclics in the interval (n2, (n + 1)2) is asymptotic to (10).

title: asymptotic k-fold Legendre for primes
stmt: As n → ∞, Lp(n) is asymptotic to a regularly varying function with index b that satisfies 3/2 < b ≤ 2.

title: asymptotic k-fold Legendre for cyclics
stmt: As n → ∞, Lc(n) is asymptotic to a regularly varying function with index that satisfies 1 ≤ b ≤ 2.

title: near-square analog for cyclics
stmt: Infinitely many cyclics c ∈ C satisfy c = n2 + 1 for some n ∈ N.

title: near-square analog of Golubew for cyclics
stmt: For every m ∈ N, the interval (m3, (m + 1)3) contains at least one near-square cyclic c = n2 + 1 for some n ∈ N. For every

title: counting Oppermann primes
stmt: As n → ∞, the number of primes in [n2 − n, n2] is asymptotic to n/(2 log n) and the number of primes in [n2, n2 + n] is also asymptotic to n/(2 log n).

title: k-fold Oppermann conjecture for primes
stmt: For every k ∈ N, there exists N (k) ∈ N such that for all n > N (k), there exist at least k primes in [n2−n, n2] and another at least k primes in [n2, n2 + n]. In particular, N (2) = 16, N (3) = 36, N (4) = 46, N (5) = 76, N (6) = N (7) = 79, N (8) = 85, N (9) = 118, N (10) = 136, N (11) = N (12) = 155, N (13) = 188.

title: Oppermann analog for cyclics
stmt: For every n > 1, there exist c, c′ ∈ C such that n2 − n < c < n2 < c′ < n2 + n. The number of cyclics in [n2 − n, n2] is asymptotic to

title: k-fold Oppermann conjecture for cyclics
stmt: For every k ∈ N, there exists N (k) ∈ N such that for all n > N (k), there exist at least k cyclic numbers in the interval [n2 − n, n2] and another at least k prime numbers in the interval [n2, n2 + n]. In particular, N (2) = 4, N (3) = 7, N (4) = 13, N (5) = 16, N (6) = 18, N (7) = 21, N (8) = 25, N (9) = 31, N (10) = N (11) = 32, N (12) = 40, N (13) = 44.

title: k-fold Brocard for primes
stmt: Let B(4) = 2, B(5) = 2, B(6) = 3, B(7) = B(8) = B(9) = 5, B(10) = B(11) = 7, B(12) = B(13) = B(14) = B(15) = B(16) = 10, B(17) = B(18) = B(19) = B(20) = 13. Then for k = 4, . . . , 20 and for every n ∈ N such that n ≥ B(k), there exist at least k primes between p2 n+1. More generally, for every k ∈ N, there exists B(k) ∈ N such that for every n ∈ N with n ≥ B(k), there exist at least k primes between n2 and (n + 1)2.

title: Brocard analog for cyclics
stmt: For every n > 2, there exist at least six cyclics c ∈ C such that c2

title: k-fold Brocard analog for cyclics
stmt: For every k ∈ N, there exists C(k) ∈ N such that for every n ∈ N with n ≥ C(k), there exist at least k cyclic numbers c such that c2 n < c < c2

title: Schinzel Conjecture P1 analog for cyclics
stmt: For every n ∈ N,

title: Schinzel conjecture for log2 analog for cyclics
stmt: For every n ∈ N,

title: Schinzel-type conjecture for 2 × log analog for cyclics
stmt: For every n ∈ N,

title: number of twin primes between consecutive cubes
stmt: For every n ∈ N, the number of pairs of twin primes between n3 and (n + 1)3 is never less than two. More generally, for every k ∈ N, there exists N (k) ∈ N such that for all n ≥ N (k) there are at least k pairs of twin primes between n3 and (n + 1)3. Specifically, N (1) = N (2) = 1, N (3) = 3, N (4) = 5, N (5) = 8, N (6) = N (7) = N (8) = N (9) = 10, N (10) = 11, N (11) = 13, N (12) = N (13) = N (14) = N (15) = N (16) = 15, and N (17) = 20.

title: number of cousin primes between consecutive cubes
stmt: For n ∈ N with n > 1, the number of pairs of cousin primes between n3 and (n + 1)3 is never less than two. More generally, for every k ∈ N, there exists N (k) ∈ N such that, for all n ≥ N (k), there are at least k pairs of cousin primes between n3 and (n + 1)3. Specifically, N (1) = N (2) = 2, N (3) = 8, N (4) = N (5) = N (6) = N (7) = 9, N (8) = N (9) = N (10) = 12.

title: number of sexy primes between consecutive cubes
stmt: For n ∈ N with n > 2, the number of pairs of sexy primes between n3 and (n + 1)3 is never less than two. (While 3 pairs of sexy primes occur between 33 and 43, only 2 pairs of sexy primes occur between 43 and 53.) More generally, for every k ∈ N, there exists N (k) ∈ N such that, for all n ≥ N (k), there are at least k pairs of sexy primes between n3 and (n + 1)3. Specifically, N (1) = N (2) = 3, N (3) = N (4) = N (5) = 5, N (6) = 6, N (7) = 7, N (8) = N (9) = N (10) = N (11) = 11.

title: asymptotic k-fold primes between consecutive cubes
stmt: As n → ∞, the numbers of pairs of twin primes, cousin primes, and sexy primes between consecutive cubes n3 and (n + 1)3 are asymptotic to regularly varying functions of n with indices between 3/2 and 2, and the indices for twin primes and cousin primes are identical.

title: number of twin cyclics between consecutive cubes
stmt: For every n ∈ N, the number of pairs of twin cyclics between n3 and (n + 1)3 is never less than two. For every k ∈ N, there exists N (k) ∈ N such that for all n ≥ N (k) there are at least k pairs of twin cyclics between n3 and (n + 1)3. Specifically, N (1) = N (2) = 1, N (3) = N (4) = 2, N (4) = N (5) = N (6) = N (7) = 3, N (8) = N (9) = N (10) = N (11) = N (12) = N (13) = 4.

title: number of cousin cyclics between consecutive cubes
stmt: For n ∈ N with n > 1, the number of pairs of cousin cyclics between n3 and (n + 1)3 is never less than one. For every k ∈ N, there exists N (k) ∈ N such that for all n ≥ N (k) there are at least k pairs of cousin cyclics between n3 and (n + 1)3. Specifically, N (1) = 2, N (2) = N (3) = 3, N (4) = N (5) = N (6) = N (7) = N (8) = 4, N (9) = N (10) = N (11) = N (12) = N (13) = N (14) = 6.

title: number of sexy cyclics between consecutive cubes
stmt: For n ∈ N with n ≥ 5, the number of pairs of sexy cyclics between n3 and (n + 1)3 is never less than two. For every k ∈ N, there exists N (k) ∈ N such that for all n ≥ N (k) there are at least k pairs of sexy cyclics between n3 and (n + 1)3. Specifically, N (1) = N (2) = 5, N (3) = N (4) = 6, N (5) = N (6) = N (7) = 7, N (8) = 10, N (9) = N (10) = N (11) = N (12) = N (13) = 11.

title: asymptotic k-fold cyclics between consecutive cubes
stmt: As n → ∞, the numbers of twin cyclics, cousin cyclics, and sexy cyclics between consecutive cubes n3 and (n + 1)3 are asymptotic to regularly varying functions of n with indices between 1 and 5/2.

title: infinitely many SG cyclics
stmt: There are infinitely many Sophie Germain cyclics.

title: SG cyclics mod 3
stmt: As the number of SG cyclics grows without limit, the number of SG cyclics congruent to j mod 3, j = 1, 2, 3, grows without limit, and the limiting fraction of SG cyclics congruent to 1 mod 3 equals the limiting fraction of SG cyclics congruent to 3 mod 3.

title: Desboves analog for SG cyclics
stmt: For every n ∈ N, there exists at least two SG cyclics in (n2, (n + 1)2).

title: Panaitopol analog for cyclics
stmt: If m ∈ N, n ∈ N, and 3 ≤ m ≤ n, then cm·n < cmcn unless (m, n) = (3, 3) or (m, n) = (5, h) for h = 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, in which cases the reverse strict inequality holds.

title: Proth-Gilbreath analog for cyclics
stmt: A SADS starting from the cyclic num- bers C after omitting c1 = 1 has 1 as the first element of every successor sequence.

title: Proth-Gilbreath analog for SG cyclics
stmt: A SADS starting from the SG cyclics after omitting σ1 = 1 has 1 as the first element of every successor sequence.

title: Hardy and Littlewood analog for SG primes
stmt: The counting function of SG primes obeys πSG(m + n) ≤ πSG(m) + πSG(n) for all 2 ≤ m ≤ n.

title: Hardy and Littlewood analog for cyclics
stmt: For all integers 1 ≤ m ≤ n, C(m + n) ≤ C(m) + C(n).

title: Hardy and Littlewood analog for Sophie Germain cyclics
stmt: For all integers 1 ≤ m ≤ n, Cσ(m + n) ≤ Cσ(m) + Cσ(n).
